answers.answer: Dear Sarahlee29:As you are aware of, diabetes is a complex disease and it cannot be controlled by medication alone.To manage your diabetes well, you must also step up to healthy habits. To begin with:1. Choose to eat healthy food and maintain a healthy weightFor a list of "diabetes superfood", please go to:Diabetes Superfoods - American Diabetes Associationhttp://www.diabetes.org/food-and-fitness/food/what-can-i-eat/making-healthy-food-choices/diabetes-superfoods.html2. Make physical activity part of your daily routine.Studies had shown that regular daily exercises, like walking for 10 - 20 minutes, can lower your blood sugar and improve your A1C. Daily exercises is just as important and effective as your anti-diabetic medication(s).3. Decrease consumptions of sugar-sweetened drinks and fatty, processed food, such as chips, cakes and donuts.Metformin is a very effective anti-diabetic medicine. However, like all medicines, you need to take it correctly and with caution. For more information, please go to: Metformin - Medline Plushttp://www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/druginfo/meds/a696005.htmlI do not know what "raspberry fet one" is, and I do not recommend diabetic patients to take dietary supplement without evidence-based data. Instead of spending money on unclaimed dietary supplement, spend it on healthy, wholesome food, like fresh vegetables and complex carbohydrates.Here is a link to Type 2 Diabetes and Dietary Supplements: What the Science Says by National Center for Complementary and Alternative Medicine (NCCAM), part of National Institute  of Health, NIH.http://nccam.nih.gov/health/providers/digest/diabetes-science.htmIf you'd like more information on Diabetes Management and nutritions, please go to:1.
